question.text: Directors of large organizations earn much higher salaries than ordinary employees do. Some people believe it is necessary, but others think that it is unfair. Discuss both these views and give your own opinions.

questionType.explanation: You must discuss BOTH perspectives equally (why high executive salaries are necessary AND why they are unfair) and clearly state your own opinion.
requirements: Discuss why high executive salaries are justified and necessary
Discuss why high executive salaries are unfair
Provide specific examples for each view

steps.title: Build Paragraphs
steps.completionCriteria: Complete all 4 paragraphs (10+ words per blank)

content.instructions: Fill in each blank to build your essay paragraph by paragraph. Aim for 10-15 words per blank.

paragraphs.name: Introduction
paragraphs.template: While some _____ [state the first view about high salaries being necessary], others _____ [state the opposite view about unfairness]. In my opinion, _____ [clearly state YOUR position].

blanks.label: First view about high salaries being necessary
blanks.hint: Start with 'believe that high executive salaries' or 'argue that directors deserve'
blanks.placeholder: e.g., believe that high executive salaries are justified given their responsibilities and rare skills

blanks.label: Opposite view about unfairness
blanks.hint: Use 'argue that' or 'contend that' followed by inequality concerns
blanks.placeholder: e.g., contend that such large wage gaps create unfair income inequality in society

blanks.label: Your position
blanks.hint: Be clear! Take a position on whether current gaps are acceptable
blanks.placeholder: e.g., while executives merit higher pay, the current wage gap has become excessive and socially harmful

paragraphs.name: Body Paragraph 1
paragraphs.template: On the one hand, _____ [topic sentence about why high salaries are necessary]. This is because _____ [explain the reason]. For instance, _____ [give a specific example with numbers or ratios]. As a result, _____ [state the consequence or benefit].

blanks.label: Topic sentence - why high salaries are necessary
blanks.hint: Main justification for executive compensation in one sentence
blanks.placeholder: e.g., high executive compensation is justified because directors bear enormous responsibility for organizational success

blanks.label: Explain the reason
blanks.hint: WHY do executives deserve high pay? What makes their role special?
blanks.placeholder: e.g., their strategic decisions directly impact thousands of employees and billions in company revenue

blanks.label: Specific example
blanks.hint: Give a concrete example with numbers, ratios, or specific situations
blanks.placeholder: e.g., a CEO's choice to expand internationally or restructure operations can determine whether the company thrives or fails

blanks.label: Consequence/benefit
blanks.hint: What is the final outcome of this justification?
blanks.placeholder: e.g., competitive salaries are necessary to attract and retain the talented leaders who drive organizational growth

paragraphs.name: Body Paragraph 2
paragraphs.template: On the other hand, _____ [topic sentence about unfairness]. The main reason is _____ [explain why it's unfair]. For example, _____ [specific example showing the wage gap impact]. Therefore, _____ [conclusion about this perspective].

blanks.label: Topic sentence - unfairness of high salaries
blanks.hint: Main criticism of excessive executive pay
blanks.placeholder: e.g., excessive executive salaries create unjust income inequality that harms both workers and society

blanks.label: Explain why it's unfair
blanks.hint: Explain the mechanism or reasoning behind the unfairness
blanks.placeholder: e.g., extreme pay disparities damage employee morale and suggest that ordinary workers are undervalued despite their contributions

blanks.label: Specific example
blanks.hint: Concrete example with CEO-to-worker ratios or real-world impacts
blanks.placeholder: e.g., some CEOs earn 300 times more than average employees while many workers struggle to afford basic living expenses

blanks.label: Conclusion about this view
blanks.hint: Wrap up this perspective on unfairness
blanks.placeholder: e.g., such disparities undermine social cohesion and reflect poorly on corporate responsibility

paragraphs.name: Conclusion
paragraphs.template: In conclusion, while _____ [briefly summarize both views], I believe _____ [restate your opinion with a final thought].

blanks.label: Summarize both views
blanks.hint: One sentence mentioning both the necessity argument and unfairness criticism
blanks.placeholder: e.g., executive roles merit higher compensation due to their responsibilities, extreme wage gaps undermine fairness

blanks.label: Restate opinion + final thought
blanks.hint: Clearly restate YOUR position and add a final insight or recommendation
blanks.placeholder: e.g., current pay ratios have become socially harmful and require reasonable limits to ensure both competitive compensation and social justice

content.instructions: Now combine your paragraphs into a complete essay. Aim for 250-280 words total.

Body paragraph 1 discusses necessity of high salaries with example

modelEssay.text:
The substantial salary gap between corporate directors and ordinary employees has become a contentious issue in modern economies. While some people argue that high executive compensation is justified and necessary, others believe it represents unfair income inequality. In my opinion, although executives deserve higher pay than average workers, the current wage gap has become excessive and requires reasonable regulation.

On the one hand, high executive salaries can be justified by the immense responsibility and specialized skills required for these positions. Corporate directors make strategic decisions that directly impact thousands of employees and billions of dollars in company revenue. For instance, a CEO's choice to expand into new markets, restructure operations, or invest in technology can determine whether an organization thrives or fails over the long term. Furthermore, the talent pool for effective executives is relatively small, and companies must offer competitive compensation packages including performance bonuses and stock options to attract and retain qualified leaders. As a result, market forces naturally drive executive compensation to levels that reflect their scarcity and value to shareholders.

On the other hand, excessive executive pay creates unjust income inequality that damages both employee morale and social cohesion. Many corporations now have CEO-to-worker pay ratios exceeding 300 to 1, meaning executives earn in one day what ordinary employees earn in an entire year. For example, while top executives receive multi-million dollar compensation packages, many frontline workers struggle to afford basic necessities despite working full-time. This disparity undermines the principle of corporate responsibility and suggests that ordinary employees are undervalued despite their essential contributions to company success. Moreover, extreme wage gaps can reduce productivity as workers become demotivated and resentful.

In conclusion, while executive roles merit higher compensation due to their responsibilities and impact, I believe current pay disparities have become socially harmful. Implementing reasonable limits on executive-to-worker pay ratios would help balance competitive compensation with social justice and fairness.
